bibl.title: Letter to Dear Doctor Connor
Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Michael E. Connor, May 22, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] critiques Connor's draft on yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Michael E. Connor, May 22, 1922
div1.opener:
Dictated at The Johns Hopkins Hospital, but address:
2121 California Washington, D. C.
/LC
Baltimore, Md.
May 22, 1922.
Dear Doctor Connor:
div1.p:
I am going over your piece seriatum and criticise what strikes
me: Remember, please, that to criticise is to judge--not to judge un-
favorably.

(1/) Your division of the infectable area into “endemic” and “epi-
demic” zones is in accordance with the nomenclature in Lyster's arti-
cle, signed by Gorgas and myself (1920). As I revised it, naturally
I have “no kick coming.” yet I cannot help thinking that the division
of the infectable territory into 3: “epidemic”: “endemic”: and “perma-
nently endemic” were a better one--the divisions being based on ter-
ritory alone.

1/ For places like New Orleans, infectable at the proper, seven but with
the infection limited absolutely by the season: Stegomyia activity
ceasing in cold weather.

2/ Places like--say--Colon and Tampico in which fever on intro-
duction might last one: two or three years--Stegomyia active the whole
year 'round and its duration dependent upon the amount of susceptible
human material furnished.

3/ Permanently endemic--places like Habana and Rio, in which Ste-
gomyia were active at all seasons and sufficient susceptible material
steadily furnished to keep up the infection permanently. It is this
division that I am going to adopt in the piece I am now writing--if I
ever finish it! However, there is no special reason why you should
change. What you mean is perfectly clear.

2/
clear.

(2) I do not know that it has been generally accepted that babies
play a greater part in the continuance of yellow fever than do immi-
grants. I discussed this matter--briefly as one must in a short arti-
cle--in my piece on the Elimination of Yellow Fever. You may be allud-
ing, however, to the findings of that so-often-mistaken Pasteur Commis-
sion: “Fever is kept up in endemic centers” (they mean permanently en-
demic centers) “by recurrent attacks among the indigenes.” I suppose it
is because they are Latins that this Commission is so blindly and abso-
lutely followed in Latin America.

I have never attempted to evaluate numerically the comparative total
effect of immigration and birth. Usually it is the large cities with--
naturally--many births that have a large immigration & so the factors increase & diminish together. I am sure that im-
migration is much the more important factor in a focus small in area--as
are all cities: while in a large regional focus, such--say--as that of
the south shore of the Caribbean and the Lesser Antilles, the children
were the more important factor.

3/ Exception might be taken to your argument, or rather your state-
ment, that there is no relation between the birth-rate and the number of
yellow fever cases. If you had said “yellow fever cases reported” your
statement had been correct. As you know, they are not reported among
natives--certainly not among native children in places where yellow fever
is permanently endemic, and yet I think you will agree that everyone liv-
ing in such a focus for X years becomes immune to yellow fever: that he
becomes immune only by attack. Obviously then, to your reported cases of
yellow fever you must add for each year on the average a number approxi-
mately equal to the annual number of births. I say “approximately equal”
because, of course, a certain number of children die before they are im-
munized, but all whol live X years have had yellow fever. This number of
cases of yellow fever then has been occurring in households, the elder
elder
3
members of which are immune. The fact of their not being reported--none
of them are--does not affect their infection of Stegomyia.

I will say here that during two years in Habana, during which the
Yellow Fever Board was supposed to see every case suspected of being yel-
low fever (and did see every case reported as such, and many others) that
only a single Cuban child was brought to our attention, and this one had
measles. Yet there were 4,000 to 6,000 births per annum in Habana.

(4) I like your expression “hacienda endemic center.” Also I like
your discussion of it. If, however, you consider a city as being not a
unit, but a number of units in more or less close relation with each other
and if you consider the regional foci, like--say--the south shore of the
Caribbean and the Lesser Antilles, I think you can find rather close ana-
logy in the laws governing continuance in all of them. We have never
found all parts of a city--a permanently endemic focus--infected at the
same time. It spreads from one house to another: from one barrio to another
--not always to contiguous places, because people frequently do not de-
velope a disease where it is contracted, or even close to that place.

(5) In some regions, even where the labor is not indentured, there is
little travel (which is the essential) from place to place. In such cases
elimination by failure of the human host is usually quite certain: Porto
Rico is such an instance as, I think, were the French Antilles. Guiteras
classes such places as with “stagnating travel.”

(6) You are right in saying there are not many true permanently en-
demic hacienda infections reported. That of Yucatan and Campeche--the
one I first used for illustration in 1914--is the best known. Possibly
the same existed about Coro, Venezuela (sugar) and I certainly would not
have trusted the sugar district around Trujillo to have cleared itself
spontaneously--especially in conjunction on with the rice haciendas north of
it.

north of it.
4.

(7) Your discussion of the different Stegomyia indices is clear and
good. I do not know that the index of containers is the most valuable.
If it be to measure the carefulness of the work done by your inspectors,
it is: If, however, it is for the purpose of measuring the number of
Stegomyia breeding places to the population your house index is best.

(8) Page 9. Your point that during a Stegomyia campaign the in-
dex of breeding is not the index of production (of imagos) is extremely
well taken. For some time at least the first will depend upon the num-
ber of Stegomyia in flight and their access to containers: the second
upon the carefulness of your inspector. Where you use fish, however,
the first part of this statement does not hold. You may have noticed
that in Peru on the report we mentioned “small larvae: large larvae:
pupae.” Obviously, the presence of small sized larvae means nothing in
the way of production. It was on this subject that I had my big row
with Professor Herms and other Army Surgeons about Anopheles. They in-
sisted that I stop the breeding, whereas I only wanted to stop the pro-
duction.

(9) Page 7. This distinction is particularly well taken. It means
that a city epidemiologically is to be considered a number of units--
not simply a single one. You must remember, however, that although all
reported cases occur where strangers live yet if the indigenes are being
immunized yellow fever must be occurring among them also, although un-
reported.

I do not know that it is also true that there are more water con-
tainers around hotels in proportion to the number of people than in pri-
vate houses. I suspect, however, this is usually the case.

(10) Page 8. I think you intended to use the word “lower” where
you have “higher” as the higher the index is the more Stegomyia breeding
has occurred.

occurred.
5.
(11) Pages 8 and 9 are very pertinent: very true and very good.

(12) Page 10. Have you ever used what Howlett calls “trap breed-
ing places?” They were first used by Murphy and myself in Panama in 1904.
It was when, the breeding places of election being destroyed, she was
seeking others--usually more difficult to find: Put a couple of cala-
bashes or a tinaja in a dark and shady place for her to lay in, which
your inspector can turn over weekly.

(13) Stegomyia larvae will live quite a while under a film of pe-
troleum--I mean 1-3 days. Pupae fortunately won't, but I count petro-
leum as of very doubtful efficiency in a campaign against Stegomyia.

Finally, the paper is a good paper--a very good paper--and you have
brought out a number of new points in it. Publish it by all means and
send me a reprint.

It I were perfectly well I would write you a very much better, more
logical--I hope not a longer!--criticism of it.

I still think, however, that the house index--having made proper
allowance to determine the emergence of imagos in it--is most useful in
determining the value of the work done--that is, how close we are coming
to reducing Stegomyia below the limit at which the fever can be conveyed.
This (as you very justly say) should be taken for the different sections
of the town--the critical index notedin each section varying inversely with the proportion of
susceptible people in eachsuch section.
Memorandum.

1) Epidemic:--Stegomyia present and active part of the year only.
Not active during the cold season--existing then (if at all) in the
egg stage.

The duration of yellow fever limited by the season independently of
the proportion of susceptible people--as Mobile: Memphis etc.
2) Endemic:--Stegomyia present and active the entire year.

The duration of yellow fever when introduced not limited by the
season, but dependent on the proportion of susceptible people:--Colon:
Tampico: Cartagena etc.

3) Permanently Endemic:--Stegomyia as with (2) and with a suffi-
cient supply of susceptible people to continue yellow fever indefinitely:--
Habana: Rio: Guayaquil etc.

The difference between (1) & (2) depends on the biology
of stay: between (2) & (3) on the supply of susceptible
men.
